The source location results in a radius of influence corresponding to the toxic endpoint of 0.0087 mg/l that extends beyond the property boundaries of the facility in all directions.  We estimated the residential population within the radius of influence as 16,500 persons by using the population density for the City of Fulton from the most recent US Census.  The public receptors identified within the radius of influence were determined to be schools, residences, hospitals, public recreational areas and major commercial, office, and industrial areas.  

The alternate release scenario was performed assuming that the quantity of chlorine gas released was 100 pounds over a ten (10) minute period with a stability class of D.  The distance to the toxic endpoint was determined to be 0.1 miles.  The source location resulted in a radius of influence corresponding to the toxic endpoint of 0.0087 mg/l that extends the beyond the property boundaries of the facility in all directions.  The residential population within the radius of influence was estimated as 100 after a ground aerial map survey of the area.  The public receptors identified within the radius of influence were determined to be residences and a portion of the Oswego River frequently used by the public for fishing.  There were no identified environmental receptors within the radius of influence. 

3.5 General Accidental Release Prevention Program

Due to the Program 3 status of the WPCP facility, the facility is required under Section 112(r) of the CAA to develop a Prevention Program.

3.6 Five-Year Accident History

The WPCP facility has not experienced any accidental releases of chlorine in the past five years (August 2005- July 2010).

3.7 Emergency Response Program

The current WPCP facility emergency response program requires coordination with local emergency response agencies, and includes provisions for public notification in the event of a

release.  Further details regarding the WPCP emergency response program are included in Section 8 and Appendix B.

3.8 Planned Changes to Improve Safety

The City of Fulton will continue to regularly review and revise its existing operating procedures related to gaseous chlorine to ensure that the safety of WPCP employees, the general public, and the environment is protected to the fullest extent possible.
